p: The disc diffusion method was used to evaluate the ability of the antibacterial activity of the essential oils of C. zeylanicum, O. vulgare, and C. longa to form inhibition halos against the growth of Gram-positive bacteria ( S. aureus) and Gram-negative strains ( E. coli and P. aeruginosa). Antimicrobial susceptibility tests of the three essential oils demonstrated active against the standard strains. C. zeylanicum essential oil presented larger halos against Gram-positive, and cinnamaldehyde was reported to be responsible for their antimicrobial action [ 6, 31]. Antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive bacteria has also been reported for C. longa [ 1], and O. vulgare has demonstrated efficacy for both Gram-positive and Gram-negative strains [ 32].
